content: The "Fairness in Flood Insurance Act of 2015" may be cited as the Act. Appeals of projected special flood hazard areas are addressed in the Act. The "Fairness in Flood Insurance Act of 2015" addresses appeals to FEMA regarding flood elevation determinations and special flood hazard areas. FEMA must prove the scientific and technical accuracy of proposed elevations or hazard area designations in appeals or judicial reviews. The "Fairness in Flood Insurance Act of 2015" requires the Scientific Resolution Panel to determine the accuracy of FEMA's data and decisions in disputes by clear and convincing evidence. The deadline for appeals under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is extended to six months. The "Fairness in Flood Insurance Act of 2015" extends the deadline for appeals under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to six months and amends reimbursement for costs of appeal. If successful in appealing any aspect of a flood map, the individual or community can be reimbursed for expenses incurred, such as legal services and expert consultations, based on the ratio of the successful portion of the appeal. The "Fairness in Flood Insurance Act of 2015" extends the deadline for appeals under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to six months and amends reimbursement for costs of appeal. The Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency must issue guidance within six months of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. REVISIONS OF EXISTING FLOOD INSURANCE MAPS; APPEALS. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to require the Administrator to update flood maps upon necessity or request from State or local governments or property owners. The Administrator must update flood maps upon request from property owners or state/local governments, providing necessary revisions or modifications. The Administrator shall provide property owners with a Letter of Map Amendment or Revision upon request, detailing any changes to floodplain areas or flood-risk zones. Updates to flood maps must reflect changes made since the most recent update. APPEALS REGARDING EXISTING FLOOD MAPS. Appeals of Existing Maps: Allows State or local governments, property owners, or lessees to appeal denials of flood map updates based on scientific or technical inaccuracies or mitigating factors. The curr_chunk discusses the appeals process for decisions related to flooding, including various natural and manmade topographical features. The process involves final adjudication on the record and the opportunity for an administrative hearing. If an appeal does not result in a favorable decision, parties can further appeal to the Scientific Resolution Panel. The appeals process for flooding decisions involves recommendations to the Administrator or the Federal district court. Parties can appeal first to the Administrator and then to the court. The burden of proof lies with the Administrator to prove the scientific and technical correctness of proposed elevations or flood hazard area designations. The appeals process allows policyholders to cancel flood insurance policies and receive refunds if successful in removing their property from a special flood hazard area. Refunds include premiums paid for the current policy year and the previous 2 years if mitigating factors reduce but do not eliminate the risk. The Administrator may reduce flood insurance coverage and provide refunds to policyholders based on successful appeals, with additional relief possible. The Administrator may reimburse individuals or communities for expenses incurred during a successful appeal related to flood map designations, including legal and expert services. The Administrator can use funds from the National Flood Insurance Fund for necessary expenses. Guidance will be issued to implement this subsection without notice and comment requirements. The deadline for issuing guidance is within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. CONSIDERATION OF FLOOD MITIGATION FACTORS IN ESTABLISHING FLOOD HAZARD AREAS. The Administrator and the Technical Mapping Advisory Council must consider factors that mitigate flood risk when identifying flood hazard areas. This includes ditches, banks, walls, vegetation, levees, lakes, dams, reservoirs, basins, and retention ponds. SEC. 6. CONSIDERATION OF COASTAL AND INLAND LOCATIONS IN PREMIUM RATES. SEC. 6. CONSIDERATION OF COASTAL AND INLAND LOCATIONS IN PREMIUM RATES. Amendments are made to the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 to factor in differences between properties in coastal and inland areas when determining premium rates. The Administrator of FEMA is required to update rate tables within 180 days to reflect these changes. The Insurance Program will implement amendments to reflect differences between properties in coastal and inland areas. SEC. 7. STREAMLINING OF FLOOD MAP PROCESSES. The Administrator of FEMA will consult with the Technical Mapping Advisory Council to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and help communities appeal flood designations. A report with recommendations must be submitted to relevant committees within a year of this Act's enactment. The Administrator of FEMA will consult with the Technical Mapping Advisory Council to develop recommendations for improving efficiency and reducing costs related to flood designations. These recommendations must be submitted to relevant committees within a year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8 of the Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014 amends Section 24 to ensure sufficient staffing for the Office of Flood Insurance Advocate. The Administrator must provide necessary staff for the Advocate's duties, including direct conversations with insurance agents, within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the adequacy of flood maps established by FEMA under the National Flood Insurance Act. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within 6 months. Additionally, there will be a GAO study on the effects of changing the base flood. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on changing the standard for designation of special flood hazard areas from 1% to 10% chance of flooding. A report will be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act.
